Award.AwardTitle: NSF Scholar Program for Computing and Mathematics Majors

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration: This project focuses on recruiting academically talented, but financially needy students into the high technology disciplines of Computer Science, Computer Information Systems, Computer Systems Engineering, Information Technology and Mathematics. The project builds on the rich scholarship infrastructure that has been created at the University of Houston-Clear Lake. This infrastructure includes faculty mentoring, peer mentoring, partnerships with the surrounding community colleges, career enrichment activities, and a strong placement program. Through the current project, this infrastructure is enhanced by an incentive-based system to encourage increased participation of faculty mentors, S-STEM scholars, community college instructors and industrial partners. The project plans to award 18 scholarships with an average of $7,300 annually for four years.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project awarded 64 scholarships to academically proficient and financially challenged students at the University of Houston-Clear Lake (UHCL) in five STEM programs in five years: Computer Science (CS), Computer Information Systems (CIS), Computer Engineering (CENG), Information Technology (IT) and Mathematics (MATH). A focus on minority recruitment and retention resulted in 34.3%, 32.8% and 9.4% of scholars being female, Hispanic and black, respectively. These numbers are significantly higher than that of comparable non-scholar cohorts at UHCL. Prior to 2014 UHCL was an upper-level institution (no freshmen or sophomores). The three-year graduation rate of the NSF scholars is 86.1%. This rate nearly doubles that of the three-year graduation rate of comparable cohorts within UHCL. 93.75% of the scholars received or are expected to graduate with a Bachelor’s degree in a STEM major.

The project had a strong career support infrastructure based on faculty, industrial, and peer mentoring. Scholars were required to attend various mentoring and career-building activities. They are members of the UHCL NSF Scholar Organization. The self-governing organization planned and organized many activities, including seminars, participation in UHCL’s student government association, industrial luncheons, workshops, etc.

The project provided incentives for scholars to participate in career-building activities and conduct undergraduate research through increased scholarship award amounts. Out of the 64 scholars, 27 served as executive members of the UHCL NSF Scholar Organization, with six of them as the president. Eight scholars have published five refereed papers in conferences and journals as co-authors. They have made four external conference presentations and 9 internal UHCL conference presentations. Our experience and insight gained on STEM education and scholarship from the project are disseminated though some of these papers and presentations.
